metadata.h1: Things I wish I knew before joining Metis Singapore Data Science Bootcamp

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: other blog posts about my projects

5 Tips For Getting A Data Science Job

all_paragraphs: This isn’t meant to be a short 5 minutes read (and it shouldn’t be anyway if you want an insight into what you’re getting yourself into). Spoiler alert: Every single day is an uphill battle.

The Metis Singapore Data Science Bootcamp is a 12-week long intensive program focused on Python Programming where you learn about Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), Statistical Modelling and Big Data tools through the completion of 5 projects.
These Bootcamps are known for being notoriously intense — and they are. Imagine cramming 1–2 years’ worth of information into just 3 months.

Every single day, I start my mornings with Pair Programming exercises, grab a 5 minutes break, then go straight to lessons immediately after. I’d break for lunch and come back for more lessons, which typically end around late afternoon at 3–4 pm.

While lessons have ended, I wasn’t done with my day yet. Whatever free time I had was spent struggling to keep up with concepts I had learned the day before (or even further back) whilst at the same time, working on self-initiated projects with 2 week deadlines. And this whole cycle repeats itself for the entire 3 months.

While it has been excruciatingly difficult, I can’t say I didn’t benefit from it at all. Prior to the Bootcamp, I was a self-studying junkie (Youtube, LeetCode, reading Data Science articles) and thinking I was progressing along fine. Until I got into the Bootcamp — which severely challenged that perspective. I’m glad I went for it because I would’ve been stuck in my little bubble thinking everything was fine, when in-fact, wasn’t. The bootcamp made me realize that there was a lot more to learn in the field of Data Science, and equipped me with enough knowledge to legitimately get started on my own.

It is extremely Statistics and Math-intensive, and these are the things I wish I knew before joining as well as the recommendations I have for you that are not a GOOD TO HAVE but a MUST HAVE before joining one.

Surprise surprise. This is a Data-Related field. Obviously most, if not all, of your findings are going to come out in the form of graphs. You have to love looking at graphs, working with them, tweaking them (bar charts, line plots, scatter plots, etc.) and you definitely have to love sharing your findings with them.

You question everything and want to verify the truth behind facts/figures presented to you. This is important because you are in a data-related field and you want to know if the data you’re getting is valid.

If this sounds like you, that’s perfect because Statistics serves as a tool that allows you to make sense of, quantify and also test the validity of a dataset, which gives you confidence that your hypothesis is true and your model works. Which leads me to my next point.

You also must know how (or at least appreciate) to apply Statistics in a pragmatic manner. With only 3 months in the bootcamp, the hyper-speed pace of each passing day isn’t gonna wait for you to fully understand a concept before you’re slapped in the face by another the very next day. Which also leads me to my next point.

I’m talking about calculus, like log, ln, differential equations, and etc. To understand statistical concepts and appreciate how to use them, you will need a sound grasp of mathematics. If you don’t, you’ll start realizing that you will be left in the dust as each day passes by.

If you don’t have these, I’d say you’ll be in for a rough ride. I didn’t even know what Linear Regression was prior to joining, and I recommend that you gain at least an intermediate level of Statistics and Math if you want to get the best bang for your buck and survive this bootcamp.
If you think you’re well-prepared and the 4 aforementioned points like fun, then perfect! We can move on to talking about how you can cope with the coming 3 months.

If you don’t know and you don’t ask — you’re only hurting yourself because you’ll stay clueless if you don’t. It’s not absurd if you don’t know the content (I mean — that’s why you signed up for the bootcamp, right?). It’s only absurd when you’re not clarifying your doubts when you know you have one.

I don’t mean this in the sense that you don’t try your best and that it’s okay to slack off when you have lapses of knowledge — but realize that trying to get a grasp on everything before you start moving to the next step results in you being way too slow and can lead you to end up not doing anything.

This has stunted me from even starting a project. I wanted to know every single bit of code, study Linear Regression first and arm myself with a full arsenal of knowledge before beginning my project. As a result, I was left with very little time to do any actual work nearing the end and produced less-than-desirable results.
You’re never going to know everything at every stage of the way, and you’re never going to be fully prepared. I never thought I’d be so cliche as to use a overused quote, but as Nike put it,

And really — just do it. There are going to be many times where you don’t know anything, and that’s fine. That’s why you’re in the bootcamp in the first place. If anything, you can always consult Google. You’re gonna be using new code you have completely zero clue about even as you type it into your Jupyter Notebooks, and that’s okay. Because you will learn after you use it.
You always have to move forward every single day.

The best way to learn is through an ITERATIVE PROCESS. When you start a project, you will hit many roadblocks. And as painful as it is, you have to live with not knowing what to expect — sometimes even not knowing how to google for an answer or not even knowing the right questions. It’s fine. Just stay disciplined and push through. If you don’t know, don’t stay stuck.

Try asking questions. Try googling. Try talking to people, try consulting your classmates, your lecturer, or even students from the previous batch (Black Raven (James Ng) and Edward Bingei helped me out a lot). You’re going to make a lot of friends and among them, your best will be Google (seriously, Google’s a lifesaver. Oh, and StackOverflow too).

After you solve a problem in your project, you’ll feel a great sense of achievement — and then immediately get stuck again on a new issue (which is pretty normal, by the way). Which then brings me to my next point...

Things in this field are constantly moving, changing. To be honest, coding used to be a unicorn skill back then. Now everybody pretty much every Tom, Dick and Harry can code. You have to stay at the top, and to be at the top, you have to be learning continuously. You have to love the learning process.
Apple wasn’t built in a day and neither are any of the projects you embark on during this camp. Understand that a project is an on-going, built-on-previous-attempts process.

You can have an impressive end-goal of what you want out of your project in mind, and draw out a huge Gantt chart of how you want to go about completing it, but the reality is, there are going to be a lot of obstacles that prevent you from doing so (things never going to go 100% according to plan anyway).
Don’t be so hung up if weren’t able to build something amazing on the first try. Focus on completing something simple first, then improve once you’re done!

I think the above image presents the concept of Project Design the best. The idea of the creation of cars never stemmed from having the idea of a car itself. It spawned from the overarching idea of an increasing demand and need for better transportation options.

Likewise, your projects will follow a process very much like this one. An overarching idea of what to achieve, and you improve on it (maybe even create a different product than you had initially envisioned) after CREATING YOUR FIRST FINISHED PRODUCT.

Yeah, it is a lot. That’s why it’s called a bootcamp. And know that it’s going to be hard — and that’s okay. You’re not alone. If you must know, I suffered A LOT during this time. Think staying up till 4am to rehearse and create slides for your presentation, and just getting a measly 2 hours of sleep before waking up to shower, freshen up and head over to Metis for your presentation.

But it does get better. Because with each passing project, you become more proficient in coding, more familiar with Python and its syntax, the appropriate Statistical Packages to use, and become better with presentation and communication (which, I must say, is great because I love speaking to people). The journey is painful but when you look back, you’ll be proud of what you have achieved — having survived that crazy and intense schedule and also having 5 Data Science projects under your belt.

Just like how I emphasized that Project Design is an iterative process, so is your learning. Here are some tips you can keep in mind when you do your projects while you keep up the fast-paced syllabus.

Keep ahead of the syllabus. Even if you haven’t covered the statistical concept(which model to use) or programming syntax to be used in your projects in class yet, read ahead and do your project alongside the lesson plans.

You’re Gromit laying down the tracks and the train’s the curriculum. It be like that. Get your project done up till the point where the instant you learn about your new statistical model in class, you’re ready to plop it into your project as that lesson ends.
Time management will be a huge issue because of the tight deadlines in this camp. However, these deadlines don’t have to be your downfall.

Your projects will always end with a presentation and a blog post (Not like this one, silly. Like my other blog posts about my projects). Don’t wait till you’ve finished writing all your code and analysis then you begin to start on them.
Do your slides and write your blog post concurrently while your model trains, or when you’re running a really long web-scraper. Get creative with how you can slot bits and pieces of work in!

The requirement of graduating the Bootcamp is the completion of all 5 projects in the syllabus, 4 of which are self-initiated and self-led projects, each with an overarching statistical concept that you are expected to demonstrate after you’ve learned them (please follow Tip 1: Start early and Study Ahead).
Project 2: Linear Regression Project 3: Supervised LearningProject 4: Natural Language ProcessingProject 5: Passion Project (whatever you want)

I suggest coming up with some idea of what you want to do before going into the camp, because most of your time will be spent learning the bootcamp material rather than brainstorming on what to do for the projects.

It doesn’t have to be very concrete, because you can refine these ideas as you progress with the bootcamp (and you have your instructor and your classmate to bounce ideas off with too). But you have to at least have an inkling of what you want to do if you don’t want to be fussing over what to do while also keeping up with very technically-heavy material of the bootcamp.
Remember why you’re in this camp. Are you doing it in hopes of employment? Are you doing just to up-skill? Perhaps a quote from The TechLead can shed some light on this.
“I’m not good at coding, but my at least code has business value.”

Ok, it isn’t actually verbatim but it’s pretty much inferred from his video here. What value does your code/project bring to the world? A good coder is not a memory storage (one who remembers all the syntax in a coding language), but rather one who knows what value his PRODUCT can bring to the world. Likewise, your projects should be one where people can see value in. Ask yourself these questions:
You can refer to this for ideas. If not, you’re also more than welcome to explore the blogs I’ve written about the projects I’ve done during the camp!

If you don’t feel a shred of worry from everything I’ve said so far, GREAT! Go on a holiday before the camp because those 3 months are going to be one helluva ride. If not, forget the holiday and commit your time to preparing for it the very best you can because… those 3 months are going to be one helluva ride.

I’d also like to add, in my personal opinion, Data Science Bootcamps are something you should go for ONLY when you’ve already decided you want to pursue a career in Data Science. Not when you’re still exploring if it’s a career for you. Otherwise, every single day in the Bootcamp will be torture. There have been students who have dropped out of the program (I’m not trying to scare you, just telling you what actually happened).
If there’s anything the time-intensive structure of the bootcamp taught me, it’s that you learn by doing and not by reading.
There’s really no point accruing all those Coursera or Udemy certifications if you can’t do anything of value with that knowledge. Showcase what you can DO to the world. As JomaTech once said,
“If you made an interesting analysis, but no one is there to read your analysis… Did you really make an analysis?”- JomaTech on 5 Tips For Getting A Data Science Job

I personally intend to enrich my learning by working on projects that focuses on real-world applications. In the process, I’m sure I’ll come across many things I don’t know, and I’ll be learning things that solve the problem, rather than learning MANY things that aren’t useful.

I know I said a lot of things about the bootcamp being intense, multi-tasking, being diligent and disciplined in studying, and staying ahead of the syllabus. But the fact is; nobody can work 18/hours a day, everyday for 3 months. Burnout is very common in the bootcamp. You gotta take a chill pill sometimes.

Give yourself a reward yourself after every project. Take a day off to get refreshed, grab some drinks with your classmates, whatever. Just disconnect yourself from the material then get back in once you’re done recharging.

I really want to say I have been quite fortunate to have been surrounded by amazing classmates (of whom were leaps and bounds above my skill level) who were very helpful in guiding me along the way when I encountered any difficulties in the curriculum.
We also played a lot (we went for more than a few drinks) and that helped offset quite a lot of the pressure from the bootcamp.
Thanks for reading and if you wanna hit me up, you can do so over at my Linkedin or at xianjinseow92@gmail.com.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
